Opened pull request "Not saving markdown files with "text/markdown" anymore" (#6756) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Internally, we don't care about content type since we store type in DB, I just wanted to be nice and store markdown files with proper content type, unfortunately, at least Edge and Firefox try to save it when pointed to it instead of rendering as plain text, so we'll save as `text/plain` to provide better experience for users of those browsers.

Later, when we stop pointing to a blob directly, but render it inside Gallery, we can put proper content types back.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Server-side performance fixes for Manage Packages page" (#6752) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/6755

These fixes drastically improve the performance of the Manage Packages page.

1) Include `RequiredSigners` in the initial request for packages. Previously, the page was making a SQL request for every package in `ListPackageItemRequiredSignerViewModel`.

2) Exit the `ChecksPermissionsOnBehalfOfAnyAccount` call early. `ChecksPermissionsOnBehalfOfAnyAccount` has two implementations-- both return whether or not the action can be done on behalf of any owner, but one returns the list of owners the action can be done on behalf as well. To get the full list of owners the action can be done on behalf of, we were enumerating the full list of possible owners every time, even if we didn't care about which owners the action can be done on behalf of. By exiting the loop early when we don't care about the list, we drastically reduce the number of permissions checks that are done on accounts with many packages or packages with many co-owners.

Tested in against NuGetTestAccount on dev, **the page won't even load without the fixes**. NuGetTestAccount has around 30,000 packages, which is 6 times the number of packages owned by the `Microsoft` account.

With the fixes, I got page load times of:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18014088/49891606-c9428a80-fdfb-11e8-9cd8-fa7288d33b83.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Can't export unused PackageReference to generated .nuspec" (#7631) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I'm trying to migrate to using MSBuild Pack support for using .csproj to building NuGet package where I'm using local .dll's to build the project which I want to replace/swap to reference an external NuGet package in the generated .nuspec. 

The closest documented example of this I could find is [Replacing one library from a restore graph
](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/msbuild-targets#replacing-one-library-from-a-restore-graph) where it suggests you can replace an external NuGet reference:

```xml
<PackageReference Include="Newtonsoft.Json" Version="9.0.1">
  <ExcludeAssets>All</ExcludeAssets>
</PackageReference>
```

With a reference to a local .dll:

```xml
<Reference Include="Newtonsoft.Json.dll" />
```

I'm trying to do something similar where I want to build against my local `.dll's` that were injected as an artifact from a dependent TeamCity/CI build:

```xml
<Reference Include="..\..\lib\net45\ServiceStack.Interfaces.dll" />
<Reference Include="..\..\lib\net45\ServiceStack.Text.dll" />
<Reference Include="..\..\lib\net45\ServiceStack.Common.dll" />
```

But when using `ExcludeAssets=All` as per the documentation:

```xml
<PackageReference Include="ServiceStack.Common" Version="5.0.0">
  <ExcludeAssets>All</ExcludeAssets>
</PackageReference>
```

It doesn't get exported in the package dependency list, e.g:

```xml
<group targetFramework=".NETFramework4.5" />
```

The closest I've come to getting the preferred behavior is to use `ExcludeAssets="compile"` so my local project doesn't build against it, except this also gets exported in the .nuspec:

```xml
<group targetFramework=".NETFramework4.5">
  <dependency id="ServiceStack.Common" version="5.4.0" exclude="Compile,Build,Analyzers" />
</group>
```

I only want to avoid building against it locally but have it exported as a normal dependency. The other issue with this approach is that I need it to reference a package that hasn't been published to NuGet yet (as all packages are published in lock-step), e.g:

```xml
<PackageReference Include="ServiceStack.Common" Version="5.5.0" ExcludeAssets="compile"/>
```

The build fails that it can't find the unpublished package:

    [NU1102] Unable to find package ServiceStack.Common with version (>= 5.5.0)

I effectively need someway to "inject" the exact dependencies and version I need in the generated .nuspec which results in:

```xml
<group targetFramework="net45">
  <dependency id="ServiceStack.Common" version="5.5.0" />
</group>
<group targetFramework=".netstandard2.0">
  <dependency id="ServiceStack.Common" version="5.5.0" />
</group>
```

Is there some way I can manually declare `<dependency/>` as above so it's only used when MSBuild/NuGet packs the project? Otherwise is there a way to apply some XML transform to the generated .nuspec so I can manipulate the XML in the .nuspec before it's packed/compressed?

Basically I'm only interested in injecting dependencies when the "pack" target is run so it's ignored/inert in all other targets.

## NuGet Install NoCache Doesn't Install Latest Prerelease Package

I try to install the latest pre-release package from a nuget server with Prerelease and NoCache parameters, but the nuget install command installs the earlier version of the package from the local cache. Then I clean the local cache and try to install the same package with the same parameters, the latest version is installed as expected.

I'm not measured precisely but I think after 30 minutes, the same command installs the latest prerelease package from the nuget server.

The problem may be about the way that I name the package versions, which is PACKAGE_NAME-VERSION_NUMBER-alphaBUILD_NUMBER
e.g. SamplePackage-1.15.0-alpha58, e.g. SamplePackage-1.15.0-alpha59

Thanks

---

NuGet product used: NuGet.exe

NuGet version: 4.8.1.5435

OS version: Win10 Enterprise v1803 (17134.407)

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: 3.5.0-rc1

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet.Core & NuGet.Clients using deprecated PackageLicenseUrl / licenseUrl element" (#7629) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: NuGet.Core & NuGet.Clients projects ( https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/ )
NuGet version; 4.9.2
dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate):  v2.1.6 SDK 2.1.500

Currently when compiling the NuGet.Core & NuGet.Clients projects you get an error because projects use `licenseUrl` element which as of a couple of weeks back with the 4.9.x release is deprecated.
```diff
- error NU5125: The 'licenseUrl' element will be deprecated. Consider using the 'license' element instead.
```

Currently the used settings are ( https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/87f433bbf1240aaa42d91d2d5955767a857a4699/build/config.props#L46 )
```xml
<PackageLicenseUrl>https://aka.ms/nugetlicense</PackageLicenseUrl>
```

https://aka.ms/nugetlicense redirects to https://raw.githubusercontent.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/dev/LICENSE.txt which at least at this moment means you get https://raw.githubusercontent.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/87f433bbf1240aaa42d91d2d5955767a857a4699/LICENSE.txt, but that could be subject to change in the future.

New recommendation is to use [Self-Contained NuGet Packages - License](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/4628) using new `PackageLicenseExpression` / `license` or `PackageLicenseFile` element. For NuGet this would mean for csproj

```xml
<PackageLicenseExpression>Apache-2.0</PackageLicenseExpression>
```

and nuspec
```xml
<license type="expression">Apache-2.0</license>
```

according to [NuGet License expressions & embedded licenses technical design](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Packaging-License-within-the-nupkg-(Technical-Spec)#license-expression-pack).

I would happily propose a PR to address this.

A quick search resulted in these files
```diff
+ build\config.props:46
+ src\NuGet.Clients\NuGet.CommandLine\NuGet.CommandLine.nuspec:8
+ src\NuGet.Clients\NuGet.SolutionRestoreManager.Interop\NuGet.SolutionRestoreManager.Interop.csproj:12
+ src\NuGet.Clients\NuGet.VisualStudio\NuGet.VisualStudio.csproj:20
+ src\NuGet.Core\NuGet.Localization\NuGet.Localization.nuspec:9
```


Also noted assembly meta data says copyright Microsoft
```xml
<Copyright>© Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.</Copyright>
```
whereas the license linked to in nupkg's says
```
Copyright (c) .NET Foundation and Contributors.
```

This might be in order, but if not I could correct that to in the PR.

Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
VS Version: D16.0 28410.60
OS Version: 17763.RS5_Release.180914-1434.
NuGet Version: Dev-nkolev92-fixlnteropBuild\Local
## Detailed repro steps
1. Launch VS.
2. Create a new ASP.NET Web Application (.NET Framework) project.
## Expected 
The project should be created correctly.
## Actual
Nothing created as below screenshot.
![created failed](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40230425/49859024-797eb600-fe31-11e8-9418-f29a3f747190.PNG)
## Notes
1. The issue also repro on all Web Site templates.
2. The issue does not repro on ASP.NET Core Web Application.
3. The issue does not repro before installing NuGet Client Dev-nkolev92-fixlnteropBuild\Local
